Amanda M.

Phoenix, AZ

"A lot of part time jobs are time-consuming and take a lot of energy. This job is easy and manageable. It makes money fast."

  • What made you decide to drive for Lyft?

    When I first signed up for Lyft, I was a grad student working on my masters. Being a full-time grad student, I desperately wanted extra income. Still, I did not want to commit to an employer and call out when I had a lot of tests, projects, or papers. I did not think that would be fair to the employer. Ultimately, my top priority was finishing my master’s degree. Signing up to work when I had free time was incredibly lucrative. This allowed me to make extra money fast because there is a way to get money as soon as you have made fifty dollars.

  • Overall, how do you feel about the Lyft driver experience?

    Driving for Lyft has been the best part time job that I have had. A lot of part time jobs are time-consuming and take a lot of energy. This job is easy and manageable. It makes money fast. I also get to work on my own schedule. This has been invaluable. Some Lyft drivers work only on the weekends. Others tend to work part time.

  • How much do you make driving for Lyft?

    On a typical week, I make $300-500. I will put in about twenty hours in a week. I have met drivers that bulk up on shifts around holidays or special events. These allow them to make $500 or even $1000 dollars over the course of a weekend. Still, there definitely are a core group of people working this job full time. If you work fulltime, you could make $800-1000 a week. That is great money! Earnings depend on the time of day and how many clients I get. Earnings may depend on the area that you live in. For example, I live in the Phoenix metro area. Here, we do not get much traffic but drive further distances. I have driven for Lyft in Los Angeles, where there is more traffic. Los Angeles tends to pay more, just because there are nonstop clients

  • What are my favorite parts of the job?

    Since this is a part time job, that was highly beneficial for me. The sign-up process was pretty easy as well. The best benefit is being able to meet people. I have met tourists, locals, and people of all ages. I have had interesting conversations and learned about a lot of new sites and places in my area. This has been a really valuable experience. I often look forward to driving, much more than previous jobs.

  • What are the downsides?

    Like anything else, there are a few drawbacks. There is wear and tear on your car. Any ridesharing job does not cover the maintenance or gas. I find that this is minimal, especially if you are only working part time. I am putting about 15,000 miles a year on my car. Although, only about a third of the miles are from driving Lyft. There is also gas costs. Gas in my area is pretty cheap and I find that I am not using drastically more than I did before I started driving for Lyft. It's typically only one to two tanks of gas a week more.

  • Any final thoughts / comments?

    Still, I think the benefits way outweigh the costs. Whether you are working on another venture, in school, or just want to subsidize your full-time job, Lyft driving can be a great venture.
